awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Last Gasp - Shutting Down Massive Galaxies at z ~ 0.6
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will study distant galaxies in the midst of shutting down their last burst of star formation and metamorphosing from spiral galaxies - like the Milky Way - into round and dead elliptical galaxies. Although this process is common, as most large galaxies are ellipticals while young galaxies are spirals, it is poorly understood. This project will use the detailed properties of newly transformed galaxies in stars and gas to test formation models. The broader impacts will support underrepresented minority students transition to graduate school through bridge programs at Princeton University and the University of Pittsburgh.

This work assesses possible quenching mechanisms using a unique sample of intermediate-redshift massive post-starburst galaxies. These galaxies have recently quenched their major star-forming episode - yet they are sufficiently nearby that multi-wavelength observations can illuminate their detailed, spatially resolved stellar properties and molecular gas reservoirs. By combining the resolved kinematics, distribution of stellar ages, remaining gas content, and visual morphologies of this statistical sample of recently quenched massive galaxies and comparing with the timescales and stochasticity of quenching within the SIMBA cosmological simulations, this project will determine the dominant quenching mechanism(s) driving the transformation of blue star forming, rotating, disk galaxies into red-and-dead, kinematically hot, spheroids. In addition, the team will extend a proven program to broaden and strengthen support of post-baccalaureate students at Princeton and the University of Pittsburgh.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed at understanding the physical processes that are responsible for driving the shut down (or quenching) of star formation in massive galaxies. We focused our study on a sample of massive ''post-starburst'' galaxies caught in transition, targeting galaxies at "intermediate redshifts" that are distant enough that we see them billions of years in the past when this process primarily happened but close enough that we can study them in detail. For this sample of ~1300 galaxies, we have revealed some mysteries and found a few answers about how quenching of massive galaxies occurred in the second half of the history of the Universe.

For this project, we started by developing and applying specialized modeling tools to analyze the light (and spectra) of each galaxy to infer a history of star formation, validate their post-starburst nature, and measure how long before observation each shut down. We studied their detailed properties to obtain hints about why they stop forming stars. High resolution images of the galaxies demonstrated that, although star forming progenitors are usually more extended disks (like the Milky Way), these post starburst galaxies were already compact, like the older population of galaxies or even smaller. This implies that the quenching process must either preferentially happen in compact galaxies or it must also simultaneously shrink their sizes. This transformation also appears to be global, not inside-out or outside in; we found no radial gradients in the ages of stars. For a small number of galaxies, we were able to search for signatures of rotation and found that some post-starburst galaxies could keep their regular disk structures. However, we found unambiguous tidal signatures of galaxy-galaxy interactions or mergers in the same images, suggesting that this process likely helps drive transformation. 

However, a more puzzling result of this (and a few other studies) is that galaxies do not stop forming stars because they run out of fuel (molecular hydrogen); we found that many of the galaxies in our sample host abundant reservoirs of molecular gas (up to ~10% of their total baryonic masses). By expanding our preliminary samples and combining with our derived timescales, we find that this gas disappears within a couple of hundred million years. On similar timescales, we find that the most recently quenched galaxies are also the most likely to host actively accreting super-massive black holes. Overall, we find that galaxy merging likely fuels elevated, and then diminished star formation and black hole growth in massive galaxies at intermediate redshifts. But, especially given the residual gas reservoirs, conclusively identifying the responsibility of black hole feedback in the quenching process will require further study. 

This project has provided extensive research opportunities and career mentoring to several undergraduate and graduate student researchers. Furthermore, it supported mentoring and advising for URM students enrolled in bridge programs at the University of Pittsburgh and Princeton University, contributing to an increasingly diverse participation in the field of Astrophysics.
